name: Anyuan Gao
abstracts: Our research group is actively seeking motivated and passionate graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. We are particularly interested in applicants with practical experience in the following areas: fabrication of two-dimensional devices, electrical transport, and photocurrent measurements. Additionally, we warmly welcome proactive undergraduate students who are interested in the fabrication of two-dimensional devices. If you are curious about cutting-edge physics and willing to explore and grow in the path of scientific research, our group will provide you with an excellent platform. Join us, and let's unveil the mysteries of physics together!
directions:
Probe and manipulate novel topological phenomena in 2D systems by external fields (including electric field, optical field, strain, pressure, etc.).
Nonlinear transport measurement.
Design and fabricate novel topological devices.
High-performance 2D photocurrent devices.

name: Frank Wilczek
job_title: T. D. Lee Professor, Chief Scientist
abstracts: Frank Wilczek, the 2004 Nobel Laureate in Physics, and the Founding Director of Tsung-Dao Lee Institute. He received his Bachelor of Science in Mathematics at the University of Chicago in 1970, and a PhD in physics at Princeton University in 1974. Wilczek worked at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton and the Institute for Theoretical Physics at the University of California, Santa Barbara. He is the Herman Feshbach Professor of Physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

name: Yipeng Wu
abstracts: T. D. Lee Fellow and Tenure-track Associate Professor at Shanghai Jiao Tong University. Recipient of National Science Fund for Excellent Young Scholars (Overseas). My research focuses on plasma-based particle acceleration, nonlinear optics, and laboratory astrophysics. To date, as the first/corresponding author, I have published ~10 SCI papers, including one for each in Nature Physics, Physical Review Letters, PNAS, and Communications Physics. We are seeking graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. Candidates with backgrounds in laser plasma physics, accelerator physics, ultrafast optics, and plasma astrophysics are preferred. Please see the following link for details: https://tdli.sjtu.edu.cn/CN/customize/1177?t=5d7ac5032525
directions:
Plasma-based particle acceleration, nonlinear optics, and laboratory astrophysics (theory, simulation, and experiment)
Over the past two decades, with the rapid advancement of high-power laser technology, a series of research fields involving the interaction of intense lasers with plasmas have made significant progress. Among these, the most attractive one is the research of plasma-based particle accelerators driven by high-intensity lasers. These novel accelerators can accelerate particles with extremely high gradients compared with conventional radio-frequency accelerators, holding the potential to significantly reduce the size and cost of next-generation high-energy accelerators. In addition to driving particle acceleration, the interaction of intense lasers with plasmas can create extreme physical conditions suitable for studying astrophysics in the laboratory. It can deepen our understanding of key astrophysical phenomena, such as the origin of large-scale cosmic magnetic fields, the acceleration mechanism of high-energy cosmic rays, the generation of relativistic jets, and the emission mechanism of fast radio bursts. Furthermore, plasmas have no laser-induced damage threshold and are characterized by high energy storage density and rich optical properties. They can serve as advanced optical components for multidimensional manipulation of high-power lasers, including energy amplification, pulse compression, mode control, and frequency conversion. This can enhance the laser output performance, and further facilitates advancements in fields such as plasma-based acceleration and laboratory astrophysics.
